statement.tex: %text Find the equation of the tangent to the curve \[ x = \sin 3t, y = \cos 2t \] at \[ t = \frac\pi{4} \] %
\\ %text Your friend says that the required tangent is a line that satisfies the following condition. \underline\text{Is your friend correct}? %
\\ %text Given $x=f(t)$ and $y=g(t)$, which of the following is true at \underline{$t=\frac\pi{4}$}? %
\\ %text Given the slope (m) and the point A it passes through, \underline\text{what will the tangent's equation be}? %

options.tex: %text The tangent is a line that passes through \[ A = \underbrace{\left( \sin 3t, \cos 2t \right)}_{t=\frac\pi{4}} \] and has slope \[= \frac{dy}{dx} \] %
%text The tangent is a line that passes through \[ A = \underbrace{\left( \sin 3t, \cos 2t \right)}_{t=0}\text{ and } B= \underbrace{\left( \sin 3t, \cos 2t \right)}_{t=\frac\pi{4}}\] %

reason.tex:
%text Both $x$ and $y$ have been defined in terms of a third parameter (t). Hence, what we have is a \underline\text{parametric curve}.
It is still plotted in the $x-y$ plane. But all calculations are done in terms of t.
Now, given $x=f(t)$ and $y=g(t)$, we can find the point $A \left(t=\frac\pi{4}\right)$ through which the tangent passes.
And we can also find $\frac{dy}{dx}= $ tangent's slope..
That is all that we need to find the equation of the tangent. %

%text The equation of the tangent will be %
\begin{align} \dfrac{y - 0}{x-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} &= \dfrac{2\sqrt{2}}{3} \\ \implies 3y &= 2\sqrt{2}\cdot\left( x - \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) = 2\sqrt{2}x - 2 \end{align}
